that on which Science and Invention is printed
the effect would be much better. My friends have,
from the general appearance of the magazine, re-
monstrated with me for reading it.
I also agree with the rest of Mr. Cague's com-
ments except that I do not like Murray Leinster.
I think that A. Hyatt Verrill, Merlin Moore, Taylor
and the authors of "The Man Iti the Room" might
be included among the very readable authors, who
write for your magazine and the detective stories
that you issue are the thing.
Your comment about "Gulliver's Travels" was
all right and I agree so far as you go BUT that
story could not possibly come true except on some
other planet and I must remind you that your
motto is "Extravagant Fiction Today . . . Cold
Fact Tomorrow" and so this does not come within
the range of your magazine. Also, and I am sure
that the readers of Amazing Stories will agree
with me. I do not like this magazine for its stories
of "man-eating trees" and such junk. "Gulliver's
Travels" was a fairy story. To those who like such
books I recommend the Oz books and such.
The letter of E. H. Hardy on the whole meets
with my approval except those comments on Mur-
ray Leinster. There are many stories of H. Rider
Haggard and Jules Verne which I have been un-
able to obtain. Such ones as are out of print would
almost assuredly not have been read by many of
the Amazing Stories fans. These, I am sure would
meet with widespread attention. "Wierd Stories"
runs a reprint department of stories such as these
so why shouldn't Amazing Stories? Long stories,
novel length, are, to me, much more enjoyable than
short stories, so, if you approve this, why not run
more than one serial?
I admire your choice of stories as a rule and am
only writing this with the hope of giving you more
good ideas. I especially enjoyed "The First Men
On the Moon" and "The Land That Time For-
got" (which, by the way, I had read before).
M. J. Wrigoins,
Philadelphia, Pa.
[We do not agree with our correspondent in some
of his remarks. If he regards "Gulliver's Travels"
as merely a fairy story, he is missing a great deal.
The somber minded dean of St. Patrick's, Jonathan
Swift, wrote "Gulliver's Travels" as a bitter sar-
casm on the way things were done by humanity in
this_ strange world of ours and the fairy story part
of it is merely -j vehicle for carrying stern and
often unpleasant facts home to the stolid mind of
everyday buitianity.---EDITOR.]

ACTION AND REACTION IN A VACUUM
F.ditor, Amazing Stories:
My boy has just brought me a copy of your
Amazinii Stories, with the question as to why I
have taught him one thing and you--whose maga-
zines he reads avidly and with sincere belief--
state, as a fact, the distinct opposite.
In your editorial in that magazine you state that
a man inaj; move himself about in a vacuum by
violently kicking his feet, and you compare that
to the action of the Goddard rocket.
Upon reflection, I am sure you will desire to
correct that statement in both aspects: (1) the man
cannot shift his center of gravity under the cir-
cumstances stated--though he might by removing
his coat or a shoe and hurling it from him; (2)
the action of kicking his feet, which are part of a
closed system, has no relation to the action of gases
in the Goddard rocket.
You owe quite a duty to young America, Mr.
Gernsback, and I am sure you desire accuracy
above all things.
George W. Graham,
Washington, D. C.
[We want our readers to send us their views on
this probjem. Action and reaction are equal and
opposite in the sense that momentum, mass velocity
is the measure of the action and reaction. When
a body reacts from another body, each has energy
imparted to it and energy is measured by '/i the
mass velocity. Therefore, when a man kicks,
the action and reaction of the body and legs would
be equal and opposite. But the energies will not
be equal and opposite, because the lighter legs
and feet will move with much greater velocity than
the body. VVIiat do our readers make out of this?
--EDITOR.]
